messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: A Fully First-Order Method for Stochastic Bilevel Optimization

Paper Abstract: Abstract We consider stochastic unconstrained bilevel optimization problems when only the first-order gradient oracles are available. While numerous optimization methods have been proposed for tackling bilevel problems, existing methods either tend to require possibly expensive calculations involving Hessians of lower-level objectives, or lack rigorous finite-time performance guarantees. In this work, we propose a Fully First-order Stochastic Approximation (F2SA) method, and study its non-asymptotic convergence properties. Specifically, we show that F2SA converges to an œµitalic-œµ\epsilon-stationary solution of the bilevel problem after œµ‚àí7/2,œµ‚àí5/2superscriptitalic-œµ72superscriptitalic-œµ52\epsilon^{-7/2},\epsilon^{-5/2}, or œµ‚àí3/2superscriptitalic-œµ32\epsilon^{-3/2} iterations (each iteration using O‚Äã(1)ùëÇ1O(1) samples) when stochastic noises are in both level objectives, only in the upper-level objective, or not present (deterministic settings), respectively. We further show that if we employ momentum-assisted gradient estimators, the iteration complexities can be improved to œµ‚àí5/2,œµ‚àí4/2superscriptitalic-œµ52superscriptitalic-œµ42\epsilon^{-5/2},\epsilon^{-4/2}, or œµ‚àí3/2superscriptitalic-œµ32\epsilon^{-3/2}, respectively. We demonstrate the superior practical performance of the proposed method over existing second-order based approaches on MNIST data-hypercleaning experiments.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "An iterative regularized incremental projected subgradient method for a class of bilevel optimization problems",
        "An iterative regularized mirror descent method for ill-posed nondifferentiable stochastic optimization",
        "A solution method for the linear static stackelberg problem using penalty functions",
        "Non-convex bilevel games with critical point selection maps",
        "Stability and generalization of bilevel programming in hyperparameter optimization",
        "Mathematical programs with optimization problems in the constraints",
        "A single-timescale method for stochastic bilevel optimization",
        "Closing the gap: Tighter analysis of alternating stochastic gradient methods for bilevel problems",
        "An overview of bilevel optimization",
        "Bi-level stochastic gradient for large scale support vector machine",
        "On the convergence of stochastic bi-level gradient methods",
        "A framework for bilevel optimization that enables stochastic and global variance reduction algorithms",
        "The mnist database of handwritten digit images for machine learning research [best of the web]",
        "Finite perturbation of convex programs",
        "Bilevel programming for hyperparameter optimization and meta-learning",
        "Approximation methods for bilevel programming",
        "A variational inequality perspective on generative adversarial networks",
        "Bilevel stochastic methods for optimization and machine learning: Bilevel stochastic descent and darts",
        "Automatic and harmless regularization with constrained and lexicographic optimization: A dynamic barrier approach",
        "Generative adversarial networks",
        "Randomized stochastic variance-reduced methods for multi-task stochastic bilevel optimization",
        "A two-timescale framework for bilevel optimization: Complexity analysis and application to actor-critic",
        "Biadam: Fast adaptive bilevel optimization methods",
        "Double penalty method for bilevel optimization problems",
        "Bilevel optimization: Convergence analysis and enhanced design",
        "A conditional gradient-based method for simple bilevel optimization with convex lower-level problem",
        "A near-optimal algorithm for stochastic bilevel optimization via double-momentum",
        "Actor-critic algorithms",
        "Bilevel model selection for support vector machines",
        "A value-function-based interior-point method for non-convex bi-level optimization",
        "Towards gradient-based bilevel optimization with non-convex followers and beyond",
        "First-order penalty methods for bilevel optimization",
        "A review of automatic differentiation and its efficient implementation",
        "Penalty method for inversion-free deep bilevel optimization",
        "Lectures on convex optimization, volume 137",
        "Meta-learning with implicit gradients",
        "An explicit descent method for bilevel convex optimization",
        "A constrained optimization approach to bilevel optimization with multiple inner minima",
        "Theory of the market economy",
        "Reinforcement learning: An introduction",
        "Descent approaches for quadratic bilevel programming",
        "A penalty function approach for solving bi-level linear programs",
        "Numerical optimization",
        "Provably faster algorithms for bilevel optimization",
        "Bome! bilevel optimization made easy: A simple first-order approach"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in A Fully First-Order Method for Stochastic Bilevel Optimization, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
